user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketAccept_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketAccept_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *sock_token, const OS_object_token_t *conn_token,
                           OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, int32 timeout)
{
    int32                           return_code;
    uint32                          operation;
    socklen_t                       addrlen;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *sock_impl;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *conn_impl;

    sock_impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *sock_token);
    conn_impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *conn_token);

    operation = OS_STREAM_STATE_READABLE;
    if (sock_impl->selectable)
    {
        return_code = OS_SelectSingle_Impl(sock_token, &operation, timeout);
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        if ((operation & OS_STREAM_STATE_READABLE) == 0)
        {
            return_code = OS_ERROR_TIMEOUT;
        }
        else
        {
            addrlen       = Addr->ActualLength;
            conn_impl->fd = accept(sock_impl->fd, (struct sockaddr *)&Addr->AddrData, &addrlen);
            if (conn_impl->fd < 0)
            {
                return_code = OS_ERROR;
            }
            else
            {
                Addr->ActualLength = addrlen;

                OS_IMPL_SET_SOCKET_FLAGS(conn_token);
            }
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
conn_impl->fd = accept(sock_impl->fd, (struct sockaddr *)&Addr->AddrData, &addrlen);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The code passes a pointer to a member of the parameter Addr to accept so that the object pointed-to (Addr->AddrData and Addr->ActualLength via addrlen) can be updated; modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter is permitted by Rule 17.8. The pointer parameters themselves (sock_token, conn_token, Addr) are not reassigned or overwritten in this fragment. conn_impl->fd is written via a local pointer derived from conn_token earlier, not by changing the conn_token parameter itself. A violating scenario would be reassigning the parameter pointer (e.g. Addr = some_other_pointer;) or overwriting the pointer value passed in, which does not occur here.
